sn22.102:1.2.pli: “Aniccasaññā, bhikkhave, bhāvitā bahulīkatā sabbaṃ kāmarāgaṃ pariyādiyati, sabbaṃ rūparāgaṃ pariyādiyati, sabbaṃ bhavarāgaṃ pariyādiyati, sabbaṃ avijjaṃ pariyādiyati, sabbaṃ asmimānaṃ samūhanati.
sn22.102:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, when the perception of impermanence is developed and cultivated it eliminates all desire for sensual pleasures, for rebirth in the realm of luminous form, and for rebirth in a future life. It eliminates all ignorance and eradicates all conceit ‘I am’.
sn22.102:1.2.comm: The appearance here of both rūparāga and bhavarāga is unusual. Normally we would expect rūparāga and arūparāga, both of which are forms of bhavarāga.

sn22.102:2.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, saradasamaye kassako mahānaṅgalena kasanto sabbāni mūlasantānakāni sampadālento kasati;
sn22.102:2.1.eng: In the autumn, a farmer ploughing with a large plough shears through all the root networks.

sn22.102:2.2.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, aniccasaññā bhāvitā bahulīkatā sabbaṃ kāmarāgaṃ pariyādiyati, sabbaṃ rūparāgaṃ pariyādiyati, sabbaṃ bhavarāgaṃ pariyādiyati, sabbaṃ avijjaṃ pariyādiyati, sabbaṃ asmimānaṃ samūhanati.
sn22.102:2.2.eng: In the same way, when the perception of impermanence is developed … it eradicates all conceit ‘I am’.

sn22.102:3.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, pabbajalāyako pabbajaṃ lāyitvā agge gahetvā odhunāti niddhunāti nicchoṭeti;
sn22.102:3.1.eng: A reed-cutter, having cut the reeds, grabs them at the top and shakes them down, shakes them about, and flails them about.
sn22.102:3.1.comm: For nicchoṭeti (“flail about”) see Sanskrit kṣud (“shake, flail”), from which Buddhist Hybrid Sanskrit chorayati (“clear away, cast off”). This, along with several other of these similes, is in AN 6.53.

sn22.102:3.2.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, aniccasaññā bhāvitā bahulīkatā sabbaṃ kāmarāgaṃ pariyādiyati …pe… sabbaṃ asmimānaṃ samūhanati.
sn22.102:3.2.eng: In the same way, when the perception of impermanence is developed … it eradicates all conceit ‘I am’.

sn22.102:4.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, ambapiṇḍiyā vaṇṭacchinnāya yāni tattha ambāni vaṇṭapaṭibandhāni sabbāni tāni tadanvayāni bhavanti;
sn22.102:4.1.eng: When the stalk of a bunch of mangoes is cut, all the mangoes attached to the stalk will follow along.
sn22.102:4.1.comm: Also at DN 1:3.73.4 and AN 6.53:7.1, this metaphor is found at Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 4.3.36, where it refers to the separation of the self from the body at death.

sn22.102:4.2.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, aniccasaññā bhāvitā …pe… sabbaṃ asmimānaṃ samūhanati.
sn22.102:4.2.eng: In the same way, when the perception of impermanence is developed … it eradicates all conceit ‘I am’.

sn22.102:5.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, kūṭāgārassa yā kāci gopānasiyo sabbā tā kūṭaṅgamā kūṭaninnā kūṭasamosaraṇā, kūṭaṃ tāsaṃ aggamakkhāyati;
sn22.102:5.1.eng: The rafters of a bungalow all lean to the peak, slope to the peak, and meet at the peak, so the peak is said to be the topmost of them all.
sn22.102:5.1.comm: These seven similes are applied differently at SN 41.141–47.

sn22.102:5.2.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, aniccasaññā bhāvitā …pe… sabbaṃ asmimānaṃ samūhanati.
sn22.102:5.2.eng: In the same way, when the perception of impermanence is developed … it eradicates all conceit ‘I am’.

sn22.102:6.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, ye keci mūlagandhā kāḷānusārigandho tesaṃ aggamakkhāyati;
sn22.102:6.1.eng: Of all kinds of fragrant root, spikenard is said to be the best.

sn22.102:6.2.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, aniccasaññā …pe… sabbaṃ asmimānaṃ samūhanati.
sn22.102:6.2.eng: In the same way, when the perception of impermanence is developed … it eradicates all conceit ‘I am’.

sn22.102:7.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, ye keci sāragandhā, lohitacandanaṃ tesaṃ aggamakkhāyati;
sn22.102:7.1.eng: Of all kinds of fragrant heartwood, red sandalwood is said to be the best.

sn22.102:7.2.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, aniccasaññā …pe… sabbaṃ asmimānaṃ samūhanati.
sn22.102:7.2.eng: In the same way, when the perception of impermanence is developed … it eradicates all conceit ‘I am’.

sn22.102:8.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, ye keci pupphagandhā, vassikaṃ tesaṃ aggamakkhāyati;
sn22.102:8.1.eng: Of all kinds of fragrant flower, jasmine is said to be the best.

sn22.102:8.2.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, aniccasaññā …pe… sabbaṃ asmimānaṃ samūhanati.
sn22.102:8.2.eng: In the same way, when the perception of impermanence is developed … it eradicates all conceit ‘I am’.

sn22.102:9.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, ye keci kuṭṭarājāno, sabbete rañño cakkavattissa anuyantā bhavanti, rājā tesaṃ cakkavatti aggamakkhāyati;
sn22.102:9.1.eng: All lesser kings are vassals of a wheel-turning monarch, so the wheel-turning monarch is said to be the foremost of them all.

sn22.102:9.2.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, aniccasaññā …pe… sabbaṃ asmimānaṃ samūhanati.
sn22.102:9.2.eng: In the same way, when the perception of impermanence is developed … it eradicates all conceit ‘I am’.

sn22.102:10.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, yā kāci tārakarūpānaṃ pabhā, sabbā tā candimappabhāya kalaṃ nāgghanti soḷasiṃ, candappabhā tāsaṃ aggamakkhāyati;
sn22.102:10.1.eng: The radiance of all the stars is not worth a sixteenth part of the moon’s radiance, so the moon’s radiance is said to be the best of them all.

sn22.102:10.2.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, aniccasaññā …pe… sabbaṃ asmimānaṃ samūhanati.
sn22.102:10.2.eng: In the same way, when the perception of impermanence is developed … it eradicates all conceit ‘I am’.

sn22.102:11.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, saradasamaye viddhe vigatavalāhake deve ādicco nataṃ abbhussakkamāno, sabbaṃ ākāsagataṃ tamagataṃ abhivihacca bhāsate ca tapate ca virocate ca;
sn22.102:11.1.eng: In the autumn, the heavens are sunny and cloudless. And as the sun is rising to the firmament, having dispelled all the darkness of space, it shines and glows and radiates.

sn22.102:11.2.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, aniccasaññā bhāvitā bahulīkatā sabbaṃ kāmarāgaṃ pariyādiyati, sabbaṃ rūparāgaṃ pariyādiyati, sabbaṃ bhavarāgaṃ pariyādiyati, sabbaṃ avijjaṃ pariyādiyati, sabbaṃ asmimānaṃ samūhanati.
sn22.102:11.2.eng: In the same way, when the perception of impermanence is developed and cultivated it eliminates all desire for sensual pleasures, for rebirth in the realm of luminous form, and for rebirth in a future life. It eliminates all ignorance and eradicates all conceit ‘I am’.

sn22.102:12.1.pli: Kathaṃ bhāvitā ca, bhikkhave, aniccasaññā kathaṃ bahulīkatā sabbaṃ kāmarāgaṃ pariyādiyati …pe… sabbaṃ asmimānaṃ samūhanati?
sn22.102:12.1.eng: And how is the perception of impermanence developed and cultivated so that … it eradicates all conceit ‘I am’?

sn22.102:12.2.pli: ‘Iti rūpaṃ, iti rūpassa samudayo, iti rūpassa atthaṅgamo;
sn22.102:12.2.eng: ‘Such is form, such is the origin of form, such is the ending of form.

sn22.102:12.6.pli: iti viññāṇaṃ, iti viññāṇassa samudayo, iti viññāṇassa atthaṅgamo’ti—
sn22.102:12.6.eng: Such is consciousness, such is the origin of consciousness, such is the ending of consciousness.’

sn22.102:12.7.pli: evaṃ bhāvitā kho, bhikkhave, aniccasaññā evaṃ bahulīkatā sabbaṃ kāmarāgaṃ pariyādiyati, sabbaṃ rūparāgaṃ pariyādiyati, sabbaṃ bhavarāgaṃ pariyādiyati, sabbaṃ avijjaṃ pariyādiyati, sabbaṃ asmimānaṃ samūhanatī”ti.
sn22.102:12.7.eng: That’s how the perception of impermanence is developed and cultivated so that it eliminates all desire for sensual pleasures, for rebirth in the realm of luminous form, and for rebirth in a future life. That’s how it eliminates all ignorance and eradicates all conceit ‘I am’.”

sn22.103:1.4.eng: The end that is substantial reality, the end that is the origin of substantial reality, the end that is the cessation of substantial reality, and the end that is the practice that leads to the cessation of substantial reality.
sn22.103:1.4.comm: Usually (eg. SN 22.105), these four are presented without being suffixed with -anta (“end”), the contextual meaning of which is not entirely clear. The commentary says anta here means “portion”, but this is poorly attested. In philosophical contexts, anta means “extreme”, but this could not be used for the four noble truths. Perhaps the obvious meaning is the correct one: anta means “end”, which in the case of suffering and its origin means death, and in the case of the path and the end of suffering means Nibbana. The teaching would then be that all you are attached to will end in any case, but Nibbana is the end free of suffering.

sn22.103:1.5.eng: And what is the end that is substantial reality?

sn22.103:1.6.eng: It should be said: the five grasping aggregates.

sn22.103:1.8.eng: That is, the grasping aggregates of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.

sn22.103:1.9.eng: This is called the end that is substantial reality.

sn22.103:2.1.eng: And what is the end that is the origin of substantial reality?

sn22.103:2.2.pli: Yāyaṃ taṇhā ponobhavikā nandirāgasahagatā tatratatrābhinandinī, seyyathidaṃ—
sn22.103:2.2.eng: It’s the craving that leads to future lives, mixed up with relishing and greed, taking pleasure wherever it lands. That is,

sn22.103:2.3.eng: craving for sensual pleasures, craving for existence, and craving for nonexistence.

sn22.103:2.4.eng: This is called the end that is the origin of substantial reality.

sn22.103:3.1.eng: And what is the end that is the cessation of substantial reality?

sn22.103:3.2.pli: Yo tassāyeva taṇhāya asesavirāganirodho cāgo paṭinissaggo mutti anālayo—
sn22.103:3.2.eng: It’s the fading away and cessation of that very same craving with nothing left over; giving it away, letting it go, releasing it, and not clinging to it.

sn22.103:3.3.eng: This is called the end that is the cessation of substantial reality.

sn22.103:4.1.eng: And what is the end that is the practice that leads to the cessation of substantial reality?

sn22.103:4.2.eng: It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

sn22.103:4.3.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

sn22.103:4.4.eng: This is called the end that is the practice that leads to the cessation of substantial reality.

sn22.104:1.2.pli: “Dukkhañca vo, bhikkhave, desessāmi dukkhasamudayañca dukkhanirodhañca dukkhanirodhagāminiñca paṭipadaṃ.
sn22.104:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.

sn22.104:1.5.eng: It should be said: the five grasping aggregates.

sn22.104:1.7.eng: That is, the grasping aggregates of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.

sn22.104:1.9.eng: And what is the origin of suffering?

sn22.104:1.10.eng: It’s the craving that leads to future lives, mixed up with relishing and greed, taking pleasure wherever it lands. That is, craving for sensual pleasures, craving for existence, and craving for nonexistence.

sn22.104:1.11.eng: This is called the origin of suffering.

sn22.104:1.12.eng: And what is the cessation of suffering?

sn22.104:1.13.pli: Yo tassāyeva taṇhāya asesavirāganirodho cāgo paṭinissaggo mutti anālayo—
sn22.104:1.13.eng: It’s the fading away and cessation of that very same craving with nothing left over; giving it away, letting it go, releasing it, and not clinging to it.

sn22.104:1.14.eng: This is called the cessation of suffering.

sn22.104:1.15.eng: And what is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering?

sn22.104:1.16.eng: It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

sn22.104:1.17.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

sn22.104:1.18.eng: This is called the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.”

sn22.105:1.2.pli: “Sakkāyañca vo, bhikkhave, desessāmi sakkāyasamudayañca sakkāyanirodhañca sakkāyanirodhagāminiñca paṭipadaṃ.
sn22.105:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you substantial reality, the origin of substantial reality, the cessation of substantial reality, and the practice that leads to the cessation of substantial reality.

sn22.105:1.4.comm: Sakkāya (“substantial reality”) is often rendered as “identity” or “personality” based on the false etymology that the initial element is sa- (“one’s own”). But it is in fact from sat (“real”) and kāya (“substance”). The Jain form is astikāya, which refers to the fundamental substances (or ontological categories). Like the aggregates, there are five: the medium of motion (dharma), the medium of rest (adharma), space (ākāśa), soul (jīva), and matter (pudgala; Bhagavatīsūtra 1.10, Sarvadarśanasaṃgraha ch. 3). Note that the Suttas use kāya in the sense of “substance” or “mass” as a key doctrinal term for ascetic movements associated with Jainism (eg. DN 2:23.3, DN 2:26.2), whereas kāya appears to have had no philosophical importance in pre-Buddhist Vedic texts. The commentaries define sakkāya as “the three planes of cyclic existence”, i.e. all that exists. Thus sakkāya_ is the “substantial reality” that is mistakenly assumed to be a “self”.

sn22.105:1.5.eng: It should be said: the five grasping aggregates.
sn22.105:1.5.comm: Buddhism and Jainism, but not Hindusim, share three technical terms, all having the sense “mass”. For the Jains, “substantial reality” (astikāya) includes  “mass” or “matter” (pudgala), a molecule of which is an aggregate (skandha). For Buddhists, “substantial reality” (sakkāya) is comprised of the “aggregates” (khandha), which make up the “individual” (puggala, see SN 22.22).

sn22.105:1.7.eng: That is, the grasping aggregates of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.

sn22.105:1.9.eng: And what is the origin of substantial reality?

sn22.105:1.10.eng: It’s the craving that leads to future lives, mixed up with relishing and greed, taking pleasure wherever it lands. That is, craving for sensual pleasures, craving to continue existence, and craving to end existence.

sn22.105:1.11.eng: This is called the origin of substantial reality.

sn22.105:1.12.eng: And what is the cessation of substantial reality?

sn22.105:1.13.eng: It’s the fading away and cessation of that very same craving with nothing left over; giving it away, letting it go, releasing it, and not clinging to it.

sn22.105:1.14.eng: This is called the cessation of substantial reality.

sn22.105:1.15.eng: And what is the practice that leads to the cessation of substantial reality?

sn22.105:1.16.eng: It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

sn22.105:1.17.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

sn22.105:1.18.eng: This is called the practice that leads to the cessation of substantial reality.”

sn22.106:1.2.pli: “Pariññeyye ca, bhikkhave, dhamme desessāmi pariññañca pariññātāviñca puggalaṃ.
sn22.106:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you the things that should be completely understood, complete understanding, and the individual who has completely understood.

sn22.106:1.4.eng: And what things should be completely understood?

sn22.106:1.10.eng: These are called the things that should be completely understood.

sn22.106:1.12.eng: The ending of greed, hate, and delusion.

sn22.106:1.14.eng: And who is the individual who has completely understood?

sn22.106:1.15.eng: It should be said: a perfected one,

sn22.106:1.16.eng: the venerable of such and such name and clan.

sn22.106:1.17.eng: This is called the individual who has completely understood.”

sn22.107:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, there are these five grasping aggregates.

sn22.107:1.4.eng: That is, the grasping aggregates of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.

sn22.107:1.5.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā imesaṃ pañcannaṃ upādānakkhandhānaṃ assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ nappajānanti …pe…
sn22.107:1.5.eng: There are ascetics and brahmins who don’t truly understand these five grasping aggregates’ gratification, drawback, and escape …

sn22.107:1.6.pli: pajānanti, sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharantī”ti.
sn22.107:1.6.eng: There are ascetics and brahmins who do truly understand …”

sn22.108:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, there are these five grasping aggregates.

sn22.108:1.4.eng: That is, the grasping aggregates of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.

sn22.108:1.5.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā imesaṃ pañcannaṃ upādānakkhandhānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ nappajānanti …pe…
sn22.108:1.5.eng: There are ascetics and brahmins who don’t truly understand these five grasping aggregates’ origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape … Those venerables don’t realize the goal of life as an ascetic or brahmin …

sn22.108:1.6.pli: pajānanti, sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharantī”ti.
sn22.108:1.6.eng: There are ascetics and brahmins who do truly understand … Those venerables realize the goal of life as an ascetic or brahmin, and live having realized it with their own insight.”

sn22.109:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, there are these five grasping aggregates.

sn22.109:1.4.eng: That is, the grasping aggregates of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.

sn22.109:1.5.pli: Yato kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako imesaṃ pañcannaṃ upādānakkhandhānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
sn22.109:1.5.eng: A noble disciple comes to truly understand these five grasping aggregates’ origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape.

sn22.109:1.6.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako sotāpanno avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyano”ti.
sn22.109:1.6.eng: Such a noble disciple is called a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.”

sn22.11:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, form of the past and future is not-self,

sn22.11:1.4.pli: Evaṃ passaṃ, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako atītasmiṃ rūpasmiṃ anapekkho hoti;
sn22.11:1.4.eng: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple is not concerned with past form,

sn22.11:1.5.eng: doesn’t look forward to enjoying future form,

sn22.11:1.6.pli: paccuppannassa rūpassa nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya paṭipanno hoti.
sn22.11:1.6.eng: and they practice for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding present form.

sn22.11:1.10.eng: Consciousness of the past and future is not-self,

sn22.11:1.12.pli: Evaṃ passaṃ, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako atītasmiṃ viññāṇasmiṃ anapekkho hoti;
sn22.11:1.12.eng: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple is not concerned with past consciousness,

sn22.11:1.13.eng: doesn’t look forward to enjoying future consciousness,

sn22.11:1.14.pli: paccuppannassa viññāṇassa nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya paṭipanno hotī”ti.
sn22.11:1.14.eng: and they practice for the disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding present consciousness.”

sn22.110:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, there are these five grasping aggregates.

sn22.110:1.4.eng: That is, the grasping aggregates of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.

sn22.110:1.5.pli: Yato kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu imesaṃ pañcannaṃ upādānakkhandhānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ viditvā anupādāvimutto hoti.
sn22.110:1.5.eng: A mendicant comes to be freed by not grasping after truly understanding these five grasping aggregates’ origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape.
sn22.110:1.5.comm: The stream-enterer (as in the previous discourse) and the perfected one (arahant) share the same understanding of the aggregates as they truly are, but the arahant has fully let go of all grasping. Note too that the stream-enterer is said to be a “noble disciple”, which includes lay people, but the arahant is a “mendicant”. The discourses do not say that formal ordination is a requirement for arahantship, but they consistently treat the arahant as one who lives the renunciate life of a mendicant.

sn22.110:1.6.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, bhikkhu arahaṃ khīṇāsavo vusitavā katakaraṇīyo ohitabhāro anuppattasadattho parikkhīṇabhavasaṃyojano sammadaññāvimutto”ti.
sn22.110:1.6.eng: Such a mendicant is called a perfected one, with defilements ended, who has completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their heart’s goal, utterly ended the fetter of continued existence, and is rightly freed through enlightenment.”

sn22.111:1.2.pli: “Rūpe, bhikkhave, yo chando yo rāgo yā nandī yā taṇhā, taṃ pajahatha.
sn22.111:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, you should give up any desire, greed, relishing, and craving for form.

sn22.111:1.3.pli: Evaṃ taṃ rūpaṃ pahīnaṃ bhavissati ucchinnamūlaṃ tālāvatthukataṃ anabhāvaṅkataṃ āyatiṃ anuppādadhammaṃ.
sn22.111:1.3.eng: Thus that form will be given up, cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated, and unable to arise in the future.

sn22.111:1.4.eng: You should give up any desire, greed, relishing, and craving for feeling …

sn22.111:1.7.pli: viññāṇe yo chando yo rāgo yā nandī yā taṇhā, taṃ pajahatha.

sn22.111:1.8.pli: Evaṃ taṃ viññāṇaṃ pahīnaṃ bhavissati ucchinnamūlaṃ tālāvatthukataṃ anabhāvaṅkataṃ āyatiṃ anuppādadhamman”ti.
sn22.111:1.8.eng: Thus that consciousness will be given up, cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated, and unable to arise in the future.”

sn22.112:1.2.pli: “Rūpe, bhikkhave, yo chando yo rāgo yā nandī yā taṇhā ye upayupādānā cetaso adhiṭṭhānābhinivesānusayā, te pajahatha.
sn22.112:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, you should give up any desire, greed, relishing, and craving for form; and any attraction, grasping, mental fixation, insistence, and underlying tendencies.

sn22.112:1.3.pli: Evaṃ taṃ rūpaṃ pahīnaṃ bhavissati ucchinnamūlaṃ …pe…
sn22.112:1.3.eng: Thus that form will be given up, cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated, and unable to arise in the future.

sn22.112:1.4.eng: You should give up any desire, greed, relishing, and craving for feeling …

sn22.112:1.7.pli: evaṃ te saṅkhārā pahīnā bhavissanti ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā.

sn22.112:1.8.pli: Viññāṇe yo chando yo rāgo yā nandī yā taṇhā ye upayupādānā cetaso adhiṭṭhānābhinivesānusayā, te pajahatha.
sn22.112:1.8.eng: consciousness; and any attraction, grasping, mental fixation, insistence, and underlying tendencies.

sn22.112:1.9.pli: Evaṃ taṃ viññāṇaṃ pahīnaṃ bhavissati ucchinnamūlaṃ tālāvatthukataṃ anabhāvaṅkataṃ āyatiṃ anuppādadhamman”ti.
sn22.112:1.9.eng: Thus that consciousness will be given up, cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated, and unable to arise in the future.”

sn22.113:1.2.pli: Atha kho aññataro bhikkhu yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami …pe…
sn22.113:1.2.eng: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha

sn22.113:1.3.pli: ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:

sn22.113:1.4.eng: “Sir, they speak of this thing called ‘ignorance’.

sn22.113:1.6.eng: And how is an ignorant person defined?”

sn22.113:1.7.pli: “Idha, bhikkhu, assutavā puthujjano rūpaṃ nappajānāti, rūpasamudayaṃ nappajānāti, rūpanirodhaṃ nappajānāti, rūpanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ nappajānāti;
sn22.113:1.7.eng: “Mendicant, it’s when an unlearned ordinary person doesn’t understand form, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation.

sn22.113:1.11.eng: consciousness, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation.

sn22.113:1.13.eng: And this is how an ignorant person is defined.”

sn22.114:1.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn22.114:1.2.eng: Seated to one side, that mendicant said to the Buddha:

sn22.114:1.3.eng: “Sir, they speak of this thing called ‘knowledge’.

sn22.114:1.5.eng: And how is a knowledgeable person defined?”

sn22.114:1.6.pli: “Idha, bhikkhu, sutavā ariyasāvako rūpaṃ pajānāti, rūpasamudayaṃ … rūpanirodhaṃ … rūpanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ pajānāti.
sn22.114:1.6.eng: “Mendicant, it’s when a learned noble disciple understands form, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation.

sn22.114:1.10.eng: consciousness, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation.

sn22.114:1.12.eng: And this is how a knowledgeable person is defined.”
